Award.AwardTitle: Fate of Topological Semimetals in the Presence of Magnetism
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Abstract:
This project, which is supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry and Condensed Matter Physics programs of the Division of Materials Research, puts forward a systematic way to synthesize a new class of quantum materials named magnetic topological semimetals. These materials are characterized by a small concentration of highly mobile electrons with polarized magnetic moments. As a result of the small concentration and the high mobility of these polarized electrons, quantum effects can be observed at low magnetic fields and moderate temperatures within the reach of most small laboratories. The main quantum effect in the magnetic topological semimetals is that their magnetic order determines their electrical conduction and vice versa. Therefore, they can act as magnetic switches, memories, or sensors capable of operating at very small magnetic fields and moderate temperatures which is the most useful range for applications. The project relies on a feedback loop between theoretical calculations, materials synthesis, and characterizations through a combination of chemistry, physics, and materials science techniques. The cross-disciplinary nature of this project provides a unique educational platform for young scientists, from postdocs to graduate and undergraduate students. A new interdisciplinary course is designed by the PI to teach the chemistry and the physics of novel quantum materials to graduate students from both disciplines. The PI makes a conscious effort to connect his research to the society by presenting public lectures and demonstrations at several libraries to explain the physics and the chemistry of materials to the general public.

Technical Abstract:
While most of the current studies on topological semimetals are focused on non-magnetic intermetallic compounds, the PI wants to deliberately take a different trajectory to look at the magnetic compounds with topological potentials. The materials explorations in this project exploit recent advances in the theoretical classification of topological systems based on the crystalline and the time reversal symmetries. The impact of the project is to open a new direction in topological materials design by incorporating magnetism with Dirac/Weyl physics in a systematic way. The project is particularly timely due to the rapid advances in the field of non-magnetic semimetals. The final goal is to engineer novel electronic phases such as chiral conductors which are stabilized by the internal molecular field of the material without the need for an external magnetic field. The project relies on a feedback loop between material synthesis, x-ray crystallography, physical measurements, electron microscopy, and DFT calculations to identify materials candidates, to grow high quality single crystals, and to thoroughly characterize them. The interdisciplinary environment of the PI's lab provides a unique educational environment from undergraduate to postdoctoral level. Connected to this research, a new course titled "from bonds to bands" is developed by the PI for both physics and chemistry graduate students to demonstrate the formation of extended solids from bonding between atoms and molecules.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to understand if magnetism is a friend of foe to the celebrated topological properties of electronic materials. By combining the principles of solid state chemistry and physics, the PI and his team designed more than 10 new magnetic Weyl semimetals. A Weyl semimetal is a an electronic material where electrons acquire a similar behavior as the light particles (photons). The design principle that emerged from this project was based on two principles: (1) breaking time-reversal symmetry by including magnetic elements such as iron and gadolinium in the material (2) breaking inversion-symmetry by selecting lattice structures that do not have a center of inversion. With these two principles in mind, the PI and his team created one of the most promising family of magnetic Weyl semimetals, namely the rare-earth aluminum silicides. The first compound in this series is CeAlSi where magnetism is driven by the cerium (Ce) atoms. Topology is driven by the non-centrosymmetric structure of this material. Through a series of electrical resistivity experiments at the national high-magnetic field laboratory (NHMFL), the PI and his team examined the quantum oscillation patterns in these materials and found out that the Weyl nodes, the sources of topological effects, are located exactly in the righ place (at the Fermi level) in these materials. Not only the team confirmed that magnetism and topology can coexist, but they also showed that topology can control magnetism in such materials as NdAlSi, anothe member of the same family of comopunds. Two PhD students were trained on the projects. One of them is currently a postdoc in a prestigeous group and the second one will graduate in the coming yeras. Five undergraduate students were involved in the project, all of them are currently gradute students. Out of the 7 students, 4 were women including one of the PhD students.  The materials and methods developed in this project are currently being studied intensely by over 20 univerities and national labs. Two new courese were developed over the course of this project. The PI has also established a close collaboration with the public library network in Boston where the team has frequently met with families and children to explain the wonders of magnetic topological materials.
